response.answer_text: No. Math is the language of proportions physical and dynamic. It could be thought of as a philosophy in the sense that the agreed construction and syntax have become critical to our investigation, understanding and manipulation of this physical universe. At this point, there are six major algorithms: ArithmeticAlgebraTrigonometryGeometryCalculusQuantum MechanicsGoogle Image Result for https://d2jmvrsizmvf4x.cloudfront.net/8c9ZSb2gTVyOySRFWt08_8978fdd9b6b0ec277851c26f4d921f35.jpg As we, humans discover more complex patterns in nature, we amend the language to describe those patterns. Infinitesimal calculus was developed independently in the late 17th century by Isaac Newton and Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz. It is effective in describing “continuous" patterns of “exponential” behavior. Generally, there are five patterns tha present shapes on a Cartesian coordinate system: LineCircleEllipseParabolaHyperbolaThe mathematical display of each pattern is dependent on “continuity" of the underlying mechaism. A point in the domain (input) of the mathematical statement (equations) must correspond to every infinitesimal point in the range (output). That works theoretically, but patterns in nature involve entities of fixed constant value. Therefore, infinity is not going to be present in the range of any physical phenomena. That's the case with the absorption of electromagnetic radiation by matter in the ultraviolet range. In fact, the calculus algorithm predicted an astronomically high heat output, which was not what was observed in the laboratory. Without an accurate mathematical tool to predict the amount of heat output for radiation input, engineering of microwave ovens (or anything else) was impossible. Ultraviolet catastrophe - Wikipedia Max Planck deduced that the underlying mechanism was not continuous, but based on the absorption of a base wavelength of radiation or its whole number multiple. To describe this behavior accurately, he had to develop an alternate branch of calculus called differential calculus. Because it is so useful in describing the interaction between matter and energy at the subatomic level, physicists like to call it Quantum Mechanics. Without it, engineering anything electronic would be impossible. Max Planck - Wikipedia

I would differ from the other answerers by stating that that the answer to your question is an unqualified maybe. When a scientist or engineer uses math, they’re using a logical language as a means of tackling a physical problem (in, say, quantum physics) or of calculating numerical details for an artifact (say, a new airfoil). Where philosophy enters the picture is in the question of what we can know with mathematical certainty—even what “mathematical certainty” really means. I maintain that the philosophy of mathematics and the philosophy of language are closely related. This is a big subject, so I’ll stop here and refer you to Uncle Wiki. “Is math a philosophy?” YES! Mathematics is a community and culture with its own language, philosophy, beliefs and such. It is the pursuit of truth at the highest level of rigor and proof known to humanity. And anyone who tells you that math is not a philosophy is no mathematician at all. At best he or she is a statistician trying to pass as a mathematician. The philosophies of the two fields are easily summed up with similar word sequences. There are lies, then bigger lies, then statistics. There is truth, then greater truth, then mathematics.

No. The method of mathematics and it’s object is wholly different from that of philosophy. Mathematicians occupy themselves with magnitudes, relations, space, and so forth. Philosophers occupy themselves with the unity of knowledge.
